Regional Technical Assistance Report
 
Project Number: 40674  
December 2007  
 
 
 
Capacity Development for Regional Cooperation in 
the People’s Republic of China and Mongolia
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  ASEAN  –  Association of Southeast Asian Nations 
  CAREC  –  Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation 
  CPS  –  country partnership strategy 
  DMC  –  developing member country 
  GMS  –  Greater Mekong Subregion 
  PPP  –  Phnom Penh Plan for Development Management 
  PRC  –  People’s Republic of China 
  RCI  –  regional cooperation and integration 
  RETA  –  regional technical assistance 
  TA  –  technical assistance 
 
 
 
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
 
Targeting Classification  –  General intervention 
Sector  –  Law, economic management and public policy 
Subsector  –  Economic management 
Themes  –  Sustainable economic growth, regional cooperation, and capacity 
development 
Subthemes  –  Promoting economic efficiency and enabling markets; trade and 
investments; and client relations, network and partnership 
development 
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, "$" refers to US dollars. 
 
 
 
Vice President  C. Lawrence Greenwood, Jr., Operations 2 
Director General  H. S. Rao, East Asia Department (EARD) 
Director  B. J. Hitchcock, Country Coordination, Regional Cooperation, 
Governance, Finance and Trade Division, EARD 
   
Team leader  Y. Zhang, Regional Cooperation Specialist, EARD

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  Regional cooperation and integration (RCI) is identified as a priority in the medium-term 
strategy II of the Asian Development Bank (ADB), which is trying to mainstream RCI in its 
operational strategy and programs, with capacity development and institutional strengthening as 
a cross-cutting theme. This approach has been supported by the ministers of participating 
countries in the Greater Mekong Subregion (GMS) Economic Cooperation Program1 and the 
Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation (CAREC) Program.2
 
2.  As active participants in various RCI initiatives, the People’s Republic of China (PRC) 
and  Mongolia  have  approached  ADB  for  assistance  in  capacity  development.  During 
discussions on the country partnership strategy (CPS) 2008–2010 for the PRC and country 
programming, the Government of the PRC asked ADB to provide technical assistance (TA) for 
capacity building for regional cooperation. At a joint meeting with ADB in Manila in March 2007, 
senior representatives of the governments of the PRC and Mongolia highlighted the importance 
of  capacity  development  for  effective  regional  cooperation,  and  jointly  requested  ADB’s 
assistance. This regional technical assistance (RETA) is a response to these requests and aims 
to build capacity and strengthen institutions in the two countries with a view to support their 
participation in various regional cooperation programs, including the one on PRC-Mongolia 
cooperation.3 The RETA framework is in Appendix 1.  
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  Rapid  transition  from  command  to  market-based  economies  in  both  the  PRC  and 
Mongolia has resulted in a reduction of barriers to the cross-border movement of goods, capital, 
and people, with a view to expanding markets, realizing economies of scale, and promoting 
economic complementarities. In both countries, regional cooperation is increasingly assuming a 
more strategic role in national development agendas, with ADB being seen as a valuable 
partner in such cooperation. 
 
4.  Regional cooperation is a prominent theme in the CPS for the PRC. The Government 
attaches great importance to regional cooperation as a means of addressing many cross-border 
issues,  fostering  friendship  and  economic  ties  with  neighboring  countries,  and  enhancing 
regional stability and growth. The PRC has been an active participant in various RCI initiatives, 
including ASEAN+3,4 the Boao Forum for Asia, the Pan-Beibu Gulf Economic Cooperation 
Forum,5 the Shanghai Cooperation Organization, and the CAREC, GMS, and PRC-Mongolia 
cooperation  programs,  all  three  of  which  are  coordinated  by  ADB.  In  addition  to  central 
                                                 
1  The joint ministerial statement of the 14th Ministerial Meeting of the GMS Program held on 21 June 2007 in Manila 
noted “the enhanced emphasis on support for human resource development,” including building capacity and 
enhancing skills for a core group of officials in developing member countries with responsibilities for regional 
cooperation affairs. 
2   The Comprehensive Action Plan of the CAREC Program endorsed by the 5th Ministerial Conference on 20 
October 2006 in Urumqi, the People’s Republic of China highlighted knowledge and capacity building as one of the 
four strategic pillars of the CAREC program. 
3  The TA first appeared in ADB Business Opportunities on 23 November 2007.  
4  The 10 members of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN), plus the People’s Republic of China, 
Japan, and the Republic of Korea.  
5  Begun in 2006, the Pan-Beibu Gulf Economic Cooperation Forum focuses on promoting cooperation in the Pan-
Beibu Gulf subregion, which covers Brunei Darussalam, the southern coastal provinces of PRC, Indonesia, 
Malaysia, Philippines, Singapore, and Viet Nam. Co-sponsored by the PRC Government and ADB, the 2006 and 
2007 forums brought together key government decision makers from the countries and business leaders across 
the subregion to discuss issues related to subregional cooperation. Promoting trade and investment and building 
infrastructure connectivity were identified as initial priorities.

2       
government agencies, a number of provinces and autonomous regions are active in regional 
cooperation. These include Yunnan province and Guangxi Autonomous Region in the GMS 
program, and Xinjiang Autonomous Region and Inner-Mongolia Autonomous Region in the 
CAREC and the PRC-Mongolia cooperation programs.  
 
5.  The Country Strategy and Program Update (2007–2009) for Mongolia treats regional 
cooperation as a priority. Mongolia is a landlocked country, whose economy is narrowly based 
on agriculture and mining.  Regional cooperation is especially significant and offers Mongolia an 
opportunity to strengthen physical and economic links with its neighbors and realize its growth 
potential.  Mongolia joined the CAREC program in 2001, and has also been actively involved in 
regional cooperation in northeast Asia, including PRC-Mongolia cooperation and the UN-led 
Greater Tumen Initiative.  
 
6.  Both the PRC and Mongolia strongly endorse the need to strengthen their participation 
in regional cooperation initiatives, yet both face institutional and human resources constraints. 
With ADB’s support, national focal points and/or national secretariats for regional cooperation 
have been set up in both countries, based in the ministries of finance. These need to be 
strengthened,  and  consultation  and  coordination  on  regional  cooperation  among  central 
government agencies improved. Government staff directly engaged in regional cooperation 
need training to initiate, design and implement complex projects and programs with regional 
dimensions. Training is particularly needed in the governments of the border provinces of the 
two countries where many of the regional cooperation projects are implemented. There is a 
strong  need  in  the  two  countries  to  formulate  forward-looking  and  action-oriented  national 
and/or provincial strategies to guide their participation in RCI programs.  The PRC Government 
has asked ADB to support Yunnan province to formulate a strategy for its participation in the 
GMS Program. The members of the Pan-Beibu Gulf Economic Cooperation Forum (footnote 5) 
have  asked  ADB  to  help  establish  an  international  expert  group.  Both  the  PRC  and  the 
Mongolian governments have asked ADB to support the PRC-Mongolia cooperation program.6  
 
7.  In  the  GMS  Regional  Cooperation  Strategy  and  Program  Update  and  the  CAREC 
Comprehensive Action Plan,7 capacity building and institutional strengthening is a cross-cutting 
theme. In recent years, ADB, under the framework of GMS and CAREC, has provided technical 
assistance  to  strengthen  the  capacity  for  regional  cooperation 8   particularly  through  the 
establishment of senior officials’ meetings, ministerial conferences, national focal points, and 
national secretariats. The design of this RETA has taken into account lessons learned from this 
earlier TA and the GMS Phnom Penh Plan for Development Management (PPP): (i) national 
and provincial capacity building and institutional strengthening efforts need to be deepened in 
order to increase country ownership; (ii) since the Ministry of Finance acts as the national 
coordinator for regional cooperation, its capacity needs to be matched by that in other ministries 
and agencies and in provincial governments; (iii) to use resources more effectively and avoid 
duplication,  further  coordination  and  rationalization  is  needed  between  ADB-led  regional 
cooperation  programs  and  other  RCI  initiatives;  (iv)  national  and  provincial  strategies  are

urgently needed to guide effective regional cooperation; and (v) in-depth studies of selected 
priority sectors can contribute to the formulation of major policy and project proposals.  
 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
8.  The intended impact is to strengthen the institutional and human capacity for regional 
cooperation of the governments of the PRC and Mongolia.  
 
9.  The envisaged outcome is more effective functioning of national focal points and/or 
national  secretariats  in  the  PRC  and  Mongolia,  particularly  with  regard  to  policy  planning, 
coordination, and strategic management of regional cooperation programs.  
 
10.  The impact and outcome of the RETA will be achieved through the delivery of the 
following outputs: 
 
(i)  stronger coordination of regional initiatives at the country level in both the PRC 
and Mongolia;  
(ii)  strategies  for  regional  cooperation  programs,  including  the  PRC  Yunnan 
province’s strategy toward the GMS and Mongolia’s national strategy for regional 
cooperation; 
(iii)  studies on deepening regional cooperation in selected sectors;  
(iv)  regional  cooperation  policy  and  project  proposals  developed  through 
consultations and workshops;  
(v)  training of a core group of the PRC and Mongolian senior and mid-level officials 
responsible for regional cooperation programs; and 
(vi)  establishment  of  an  international  expert  group  for  Pan-Beibu  Gulf  Economic 
Cooperation Forum. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
11.  The  RETA  was  formulated  through  a  consultative  process  involving  extensive 
discussions  between  ADB  and  the  two  governments.  A  participatory  approach  to  project 
implementation will be adopted to foster strong country ownership. All components of the RETA 
will be implemented in close consultation with the ministries of finance in the two countries. This 
will also provide learning-by-doing opportunities for government counterpart staff.  
 
12.  The RETA will undertake the following activities: 
(i)  organizing in-country consultation and sector workshops to coordinate policies 
and programs for regional cooperation among central government agencies and 
between central government and provincial governments;  
(ii)  formulating the PRC Yunnan Province’s strategy toward the GMS and Mongolia’s 
national strategy for regional cooperation;  
(iii)  conducting studies of selected sector(s) in the PRC and Mongolia to develop 
policy and project proposals for regional cooperation;9  
                                                 
9  Sector(s) will be identified through consultations with the governments of the PRC and Mongolia. Based on initial 
feedback from the governments, potential sectors include energy (focusing on cross-border energy trade) and 
transport (focusing on development of cross-border corridors).

4       
(iv)  training  a  core  group  of  senior  and  mid-level  officials  from  the  central  and 
provincial governments of the PRC and Mongolia to enhance their negotiating 
skills and to design and implement regional cooperation projects and programs 
(as far as possible,  such training will build on and contribute to the capacity 
development activities of the PPP and the CAREC Institute);10 
(v)  supporting the establishment and the initial operation of the international expert 
group under the Pan-Beibu Gulf Economic Cooperation Program; and 
(vi)  promoting information and experience sharing between the PRC and Mongolia 
with regard to regional cooperation.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
13.  The  total  cost  of  the  TA  is  estimated  at  $900,000  equivalent,  of  which  $750,000 
equivalent will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s TA funding program. The governments of 
the  PRC  and  Mongolia  will  contribute  about  $150,000  equivalent  in  total  by  providing 
counterpart  staff,  office  space,  support  for  training,  seminars  and  conferences,  and  other 
administrative and logistical services. Details of the TA cost estimates and financing plan are in 
Appendix 2.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
14.  A  total  of  12  person-months  of  international  and  36  person-months  of  national 
consultants will be required to provide advisory and technical services under the RETA. The 
consultants will help to develop regional cooperation strategies for Mongolia and the PRC’s 
Yunnan Province; institute or improve a process to coordinate regional cooperation activities at 
the  country  level  and  to  conduct  training;  work  with  national  focal  points  and  national 
secretariats to coordinate regional cooperation; and conduct studies on regional cooperation in 
priority sector(s) to be identified at a later stage in consultation with the governments of the PRC 
and Mongolia. The RETA will also engage international and national resource persons to help 
organize and make presentations to in-country policy consultations, sector workshops, and 
targeted training events. Consultants and resource persons will be selected and engaged by 
ADB  as  individuals  based  on  their  qualifications  and  experience  in  accordance  with  the 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time). The outline terms 
of reference for consultants and resource persons are in Appendix 3. Office equipment will be 
procured by the implementing agencies in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines for Procurement 
(2007, as amended from time to time), and will be transferred to implementing agencies upon 
completion of the RETA. 
 
15.  The TA will be implemented over 24 months, from January 2008 to December 2009. 
ADB  will  be  the  Executing  Agency.  The  Country  Coordination,  Regional  Cooperation, 
Governance, Finance and Trade Division of the East Asia Department will administer and 
implement  the  RETA.  The  ministries  of  finance  of  the  PRC  and  Mongolia  will  be  the 
implementing  agencies,  supported  by  ADB’s  resident  missions  in  the  two  countries.    The 
implementing agencies will coordinate with various government agencies and help to (i) set the 
agendas of workshops and training events, (ii) determine the sectors to be covered by studies 
on deepening regional cooperation, and (iii) select national consultants and resource speakers. 
ADB  will  facilitate  communication  between  the  two  governments.  Monitoring  of  the 
                                                 
10  The Executing Agency will coordinate closely with the secretariat of the PPP and the ADB CAREC Unit to identify 
opportunities for the PRC and Mongolian officials to also benefit from courses under the PPP and the CAREC 
Institute. The course(s) developed under this RETA will also be shared with PPP and the CAREC Institute.

5
implementation progress and TA outcomes will be carried out through periodic reviews of the 
TA activities as per the design and monitoring framework.  
 
16.  The East Asia Department will coordinate closely with other ADB departments, including 
the Southeast Asia Department for matters related to the GMS, the Central and West Asia 
Department and the CAREC Unit for matters related to the CAREC, the Office of Regional 
Economic Integration for trade and finance-related activities, and the Regional and Sustainable 
Development Department for work on regional public goods. It will also seek partnerships with 
other regional cooperation bodies. 
 
17.  The RETA outputs, particularly the findings and recommendations from the national and 
provincial  strategies  and  selected  sector  studies,  will  be  disseminated  through  workshops, 
seminars,  conferences,  publication,  and  the  media.  Where  appropriate,  representatives  of 
neighboring countries and the secretariats of other regional cooperation bodies will be invited to 
dissemination events.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
18.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $750,000 on a grant basis to 
the governments of the People’s Republic of China and Mongolia for Capacity Development for 
Regional Cooperation in the People’s Republic of China and Mongolia, and hereby reports this 
action to the Board.

Appendix 3  9 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  A  total  of  12  person-months  of  international  and  36  person-months  of  national 
consultants will be required to provide advisory and technical services to realize the objectives 
of  the  regional  technical  assistance  (RETA).  The  person-months  indicated  are  indicative. 
Because the activities under the RETA will mostly be straightforward assignments, consultants 
will be selected and engaged by Asian Development Bank (ADB) as individuals based on their 
qualifications and experience. Given that some of the activities are still being planned, flexibility 
will be allowed and detailed terms of reference for specific tasks may be revised at a later stage. 
The consultants will report to and be supervised by the ADB task manager for the project, who 
will also be responsible for the overall coordination of the activities under the RETA. The 
reporting requirement for international consultants engaged will include progress report(s), and 
draft final and final reports, which will be translated into national languages. 
A.  International Consultants (12 person-months) 
1.  Regional Cooperation Specialist(s) (6 person-months) 
2.  The consultant(s) will help the governments prepare national and provincial strategies 
for regional cooperation. They will  
(i)  assess  regional  economic  trends,  government  policies  on  external  economic 
relations, and the progress of regional cooperation programs; 
(ii)  evaluate  the  strengths,  weaknesses,  opportunities,  and  threats  of  the 
government’s current and future regional cooperation issues; 
(iii)  develop a regional cooperation strategy for the governments that will 
(a)  identify  key  priorities,  including  project  opportunities  for  regional 
cooperation; 
(b)  recommend  steps  to  integrate  regional  cooperation  into  national  and 
provincial development strategy and public investment planning; 
(c)  recommend measures for institution strengthening and capacity building 
in the governments; 
(d)  recommend ways to strengthen the partnership between the governments 
and development partners, particularly ADB; 
(e)  recommend policies and steps to enhance private sector participation in 
regional cooperation; 
(iv)  help disseminate findings to the governments, development partners, and other 
stakeholders.  
 
2.  Institutional Development Specialist (3 person-months) 
 
3.  The consultant will 
 
(i)  deliver a report on instituting or improving coordination of regional cooperation at 
the country level, especially among ministries and between central and provincial 
governments; major constraints and problems in intra-government coordination; 
and options to address the problems identified; 
(ii)  recommend practical and country-specific measures to improve the function of 
national focal points and/or national secretariats; 
(iii)  develop a comprehensive capacity building plan to address the short-, medium-, 
and long-term needs of agencies and institutions involved in regional cooperation;

10  Appendix 3 
 
(iv)  advise  on  strengthening  links  between  the  ADB-led  regional  cooperation 
programs and other regional initiatives; and 
(v)  coordinate the design and conduct of training courses and workshops under the 
RETA, in collaboration with resource persons and trainers. 
 
3.   Sector Specialist (3 person-months) 
 
4.  Depending  on  the  identification  of  the  subject  sector(s)  in  consultation  with  the 
governments, the consultant will conduct sector studies that will 
 
(i)  assess the current status of the sector, and review the short-, medium- and long-
term development plans of the sector in national and regional contexts; 
(ii)  prepare a time-bound action plan identifying steps to be taken by governments, 
ADB and other regional bodies in support of regional cooperation in the sector 
and identify two or three highest priority opportunities for ADB’s assistance to the 
sector; and 
(iii)  assist the organization of and present to the sector workshop. 
 
B.  National Consultants (36 person-months) 
1.  In-Country  Regional  Cooperation  Coordinators  (30  person-months  for  2 
persons, with one for each country) 
 
5.  The consultants will 
 
(i)  serve as focal points on regional economic cooperation in the People’s Republic 
of China (PRC) and Mongolia, coordinating with national focal points and national 
secretariats,  other  government  agencies  involved  in  regional  cooperation 
activities, business communities and other stakeholders, as well as ADB; 
(ii)  establish and maintain long-term working relations with key government agencies 
responsible for regional cooperation; 
(iii)  monitor  and  assist  the  implementation  of  the  ADB’s  regional  projects  in  the 
country; 
(iv)  assist  in  the  preparation  of  national  and  provincial  strategies  for  regional 
cooperation; 
(v)  assist in the logistics and other arrangements for conferences, workshops and 
training events; 
(vi)  monitor programs and initiatives of the governments and regional organizations 
on regional cooperation, and identify and recommend potential areas for ADB 
assistance; and 
(vii)  perform other tasks related to regional cooperation as assigned by the ADB task 
manager. 
 
2.  Sector Specialist(s) (6 person-months) 
 
6.  The  consultants  will  work  with  and  support  the  international  sector  specialist  in 
conducting the sector study, including by researching and compiling government sector policies, 
investment planning, and translating various documents, among others.
